description.narrative: By 2020, the alternative family-based care system and community-based family support services are strengthened and accessible to vulnerable children and their families.

mailing-address.narrative: UNICEF Armenia UN Building 14 Petros Adamyan Street Yerevan 0010 Armenia

sector.narrative: Public finance management for child protection
Social welfare workforce systems strengthening (accreditation, staffing and supervision)
Technical assistance - Prevention and response services for violence against children

title.narrative: UNICEF Programmes in Armenia (Social Protection and Child Poverty)
UNICEF Contract Awards through the UN Global Marketplace
2017 Armenia: Final Evaluation of Mitigating Social Consequences of the Labour Migration and Maximising the Migrants’ Involvement in Local Development Project
Armenia 2019 Annual Report on Results for Children
Armenia Country Office 2020 Annual Report on Results for Children
UNICEF Tender Notices through the UN Global Marketplace

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2020, the alternative family-based care system and community-based family support services are strengthened and accessible to vulnerable children and their families.

description.narrative: The transformation and closure of residential care institutions continued, and as a result the number of children in state-run residential institutions decreased from around 2,400 in the beginning of 2019 to around 1,300 at the end of the reporting year. The number of children in foster care doubled. UNICEF also supported the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (MoLSA) and the Ministry of Health (MoH) to strengthen prevention of abandonment of children due to disability. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:19/01/2020

title.narrative: Number of state-run residential institutions closed and proportion of those transformed into community-based centres accessible to children in difficult life circumstances and their families

baseline.value: 0 institutions are closed, there are 8 state-funded community-based centres

title.narrative: An alternative care policy in line with the 2009 Guidelines for the Alternative Care of Children is available in the country

baseline.value: Alternative care policy is not satisfactory

target.value: 2020:Secondary legislation deriving from the newly adopted legislation on alternative care adopted and implementation started

actual.value: 2019:De-institutionalization strategy developed and to be adopted.

title.narrative: Existence of a regular in-service and pre-service training on Social Work/Case Management with a focus on children

target.value: 2020:In service training (with a focus on early identification and response to violence) provided to social workforce in targeted marzes

actual.value: 2019:100 social workers from all the marzes benefited from in-service training (supportive supervision and recap).

title.narrative: Number of foster families (FF) state funded and number of children placed in foster care

baseline.value: State funded foster families: 25, Children in foster families: 15

target.value: 2020:State funded foster families: 75; Children in foster families: 75
